April 28, 2000
GameSpot
CUC Gets Renamed
The parent company of Berkeley Systems, Sierra, and Blizzard merges and changes name.
Harley Jebens
All Out War Coming
Even though it's a little late, All Out War keeps up the battle as it fights its way back for a release date.
Harley Jebens
Nintendo Experiences Crunch
Nintendo says that it expects half a million calls to its consumer service and gameplay hint lines.
Chris Johnston
Is It Time for Legal Crime?
How hard is it to develop a game title and get it into the retail channel? Two Finnish gamers find out.
Harley Jebens

HMV takes on a new market by announcing that it will sell PC peripherals from VideoLogic.

Chris Johnston

Moira Muldoon
GT Named in Court Documents
GT Interactive reportedly faces two class action suits alleging that certain GT officers and board members inflated GT's stock price in order to sell their own shares of GT stock at favorable prices. A suit reportedly filed Wednesday seeks damages for GT shareholders who bought stock between August 1, 1996 and December 12, 1997.
Gamespot Staff
SMK Sues Big N
SMK takes legal action against Nintendo for breach of contract regarding SNES cartridge manufacturing.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
Koei's Next N64 Title
In the latest issue of Dengeki Nintendo 64, Koei reveals details on its next N64 title.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
The Journeyman Project 3 Update
The Journeyman Project 3: Legacy of Time will ship on four CD-ROM discs (in both PC and Mac formats) in February, according to the game's developer, Red Orb Entertainment. Red Orb will give away a Pentium II 300 as part of its promotion for the game's release.

Friday, GS News learned that MGM Interactive is busy working on its as-yet-untitled N64 game. The game apparently has a two-player mode, but it is still very early. It's expected to be released sometime in 1999.

Chris Johnston
Duke Teams With the Shadow
GT Interactive is putting Duke Nukem: Atomic Edition and Shadow Warrior in a single package to be called East Meets West. It's due in March and will retail for US$49.95. The package will also include an editor that will allow gamers to create their own Duke Nukem or Shadow Warrior levels.

Chris Johnston
Sony Shipments Top 30 Million
Sony announced that as of Thursday, 30 million PlayStations have been shipped worldwide. The breakdown is 10.65 million units shipped in Japan, 10.75 million in North America, and 8.6 million in Europe.
Chris Johnston
Favre Signs to QBC '99
Acclaim signs Brett Favre to be spokesman for NFL Quarterback Club '99.
Chris Johnston
Psygnosis Gives Peek Into '98
Psygnosis informed GameSpot News Thursday that a sequel to the popular PlayStation space shooter Colony Wars is currently in development. Colony Wars: Vendetta has a November release. This title nestles into Psygnosis' winter plans between the October action-adventure title, ODT, and the December hoverboarder, Psybadek.

Yutaka Ohbuchi
AOL Slices, Dices Worldplay Staff
America Online this week fired over 100 staffers from its Entertainment Asylumand WorldPlay divisions. The company also decided to terminate development of its online 3D environment known as CyberPark. These moves come just days after the company announced it would increase the amount AOL subscribers will pay for unlimited access to AOL.
Gamespot Staff
Sega Portables Invade Arcades
A report from Tokyo indicates that Sega Enterprises will begin offering portable LCD game machines as prizes in UFO Catcher-style redemption machines this summer in Japan. At press time, it was unclear whether these will be Tamagotchi- or Game & Watch-style games or an actual portable game machine.

Chris Johnston
g.o.d. Makes a Friend
On Tuesday the Gathering of Developers (g.o.d.) signed a deal with the Pennsylvania Merchants Group for an investment that should establish the company's presence while it secures more substantial funding. Sources say the company is seeking between US$25 and $30 million in capital.
Alan Dunkin
Get Some Clay...Again
Interplay releases a special version of Clayfighter 63 1/3 for the Nintendo 64 - for rental only.
Chris Johnston
Wing Commander Filming Commences
Digital Anvil's Chris Roberts will be behind the camera this weekend as principal photography begins on Wing Commander (the movie) on the streets of Luxembourg. Freddie Prinze Jr, Matthew Lillard, Saffron Burrows, Malcolm McDowell, and Jurgen Prochnow are starring and Roberts is directing the US$27 million feature based on Origin's Wing Commander series.
Gamespot Staff
STB Support for i740
STB's Lightspeed 740 graphics card joins the i740 club.
Micheal Mullen
No Love for the Dreamcast
Love de Lic, creators of the PlayStation RPG Moon, are working on a new Dreamcast title called Lack of Love. Scheduled for release in Winter '98, your character has to establish a base for human life on a distant planet while dealing with the local dangers.

Harley Jebens
3Dfx's Public Offering
On Friday, 3Dfx announced the sale of 2,028,140 shares of Common Stock for sale by the company and 871,860 shares of its Common Stock for sale by shareholders at a price of US$23.75 per share. Also, underwriters have an option of purchasing an additional 435,000 shares to cover over-allotments. This makes brings the total number of public stocks currently offered by the company to 14,600,000.
Gamespot Staff
Ray Tracers Traced to Retailers
Thursday THQ announced that it has shipped the US version of the Taito PlayStation title Ray Tracers, which combines 3D racing with combat action (much like Taito's old Chase HQ title). The game should be available at most retailers by this weekend for an MSRP of US$49.95.

Dual Shock Sighting
GameSpot News has been tipped from a source that the US version of Tecmo's Dead or Alive will be the first dual shock-compatible PlayStation game to be released in the US. Tecmo wouldn't comment.

Gex Leaps off Shelves
Midway announced Wednesday that Gex: Enter the Gecko for the PlayStation has experienced sell-throughs at many retail outlets and continues to sell well since its release on February 24. The company is planning an N64 version for the summer.

Gamespot Staff
IGZ Hacked
Microsoft's IGZ online gaming enterprise was shut down by hackers last weekend, for just a few short hours, an IGZ staffer told GameSpot News. The hackers remain at large. Microsoft is still trying to figure out exactly how the shutdown occurred.

THQ Acquires GameFX
THQ will acquire GameFX Inc., a software developer specializing in games with proprietary 3D-acceleration technology. The company is developing a PC product for THQ to be published later this year or in early '99.
Gamespot Staff
Enix Moves Ahead on Bust A Move 2
While the US version of Bust A Move Dance & Rhythm Action hasn't hit yet, Enix has already begun development of a sequel. Not to be confused with Taito/Acclaim's puzzle game of the same name, Bust A Move struck a chord with Parappa fans upon its late January 1998 release.

Psygnosis makes it official. It is now an official developer for the Nintendo 64.
Chris Johnston
Mega Man Legends Delayed
Capcom has decided to delay the release date of its PlayStation title Mega Man Legends until September. The game is finished; however, Capcom believes that the title will fit in its lineup better (and be more visible, certainly) during the fall/holiday shopping seasons.

Harley Jebens
World Opponent Network Launches
Cendant Corp., owner of Sierra On-line and Berkeley Systems, opens the portal to more than 30 online games with the Monday launch of World Opponent Network. Touting its content, info, and community, WON provides online gaming opportunities for players of Lords of Magic, Red Baron II, Civil War Generals 2, and Lords of the Realm II to name a few titles. WON is located at www.won.net.
Gamespot Staff
EB Online Store Expands
Electronics Boutique, mall and online retailer of computer games and other game-related sundries, will upgrade its online presence and make available an additional 5,000 items to online shoppers. The Pennsylvania-based company says it is "not expanding the product mix," but merely making all items available in its mall locations available to online shoppers.
Gamespot Staff
EB Online Store Expands
Electronics Boutique, mall and online retailer of computer games and other game-related sundries, will upgrade its online presence and make available an additional 5,000 items to online shoppers. The Pennsylvania-based company says it is "not expanding the product mix," but merely making all items available in its mall locations available to online shoppers.

GT's Dark Vengeance
Reality Bytes is hard at work on an impressive looking third-person strategy title for GT Interactive.
Micheal Mullen
THQ Net Income for Q1 Jumps
THQ reported net income of US$6.49 million for the recent quarter. PlayStation titles accounted for over 50 percent of THQ's revenues. Other platforms performed as follows: N64, 38 percent; Game Boy, 4 percent; 16 bit titles, 3 percent. For the same quarter a year ago those figures were PS, 19 percent; N64, 0 percent; Game Boy 30 percent; and 16 bit, 50 percent.
Gamespot Staff
Best Buy Joins PGL
Looks like the Professional Gamers' League has racked up another sponsor. Best Buy has signed on as the league's "official national retailer."

The National SCRABBLE Association's John D. Williams Jr. will be on the Internet Gaming Zone's SCRABBLE Chat Auditorium Thursday, April 23, at 6pm PST. At the same time the Zone team will be battling the Age of Empires experts at Computer Gaming World in the Age of Empires War Cry game room.

Chaimowitz Named GT Chairman
GT Interactive announced Tuesday that Ronald W. Chaimowitz, who currently serves as president and CEO, will become chairman (and will remain CEO). David I. Chemerow will become president and COO, and Harry M. Rubin will become president of the international division.

Chris Johnston
Psygnosis Publishes Power Soccer
Psygnosis says it will publish Adidas Power Soccer '98 for the PlayStation this June. The release will coincide with the World Cup taking place from June 10 through July 12 in France. The game includes 34 stadiums, over 60 special moves, and a massive 10,000 player database.

Alan Dunkin
Enix Delays Dragon Quest
TOKYO - On Friday, Enix announced that it is delaying the release of Dragon Quest VII for the PlayStation. As one of the most popular RPG series, DQ VII was originally supposed to come out in time for Christmas '98. But due to delays in development, the game is now scheduled for release next summer.
Gamespot Staff
STB's Velocity Gets a Boost
STB Systems has announced today that it is shipping an 8MB version of its Velocity 128 2D/3D accelerator card.
Alan Dunkin
Pokemon in the Flesh
4Kids Entertainment, upcoming distributor of a Pokemon TV show due to US markets through syndication says its close to signing a licensing deal with a "major toy company" to produce action figures and toys based on Pocket Monster characters. Just don't stare at the little critters.

Gamespot Staff
Koei's New Titles
Koei tells GameSpot News that Soldnerschild has been approved by Sony and that work on Destrega for the PlayStation is just beginning. Koei's Omega Force development team (they did Dynasty Warriors) is working on the new 3D fighter Destrega. A release isn't scheduled until next year. Koei's first N64 title, WinBack, is scheduled for a late '98 release.

Harley Jebens
Sega's First Original Title
The sardonic wit of Dr. Strangelove meets international warfare in a new PC title from Sega.
Harley Jebens
Electronic Arts on a Roll
Revenues for the country's largest game software company keep on growing. In the fourth quarter ending March 31, 1998, EA revs jumped 31 percent to US$204 million and net income increased 45 percent to $15.3 million. For the year ending March 31, revs were $908.8 million (up 35 percent ) and net income jumped 41 percent to $72.6 million. New NASCAR, Tiger Woods, and World Championship Wrestling licenses could propel EA revenues even higher.
Gamespot Staff
GT Board Announcement
GT Interactive announces a new addition to its board of directors.

Chris Johnston
Miyamoto Will Enter Hall of Fame
The Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences announced Tuesday that Shigeru Miyamoto, creator of Mario and Donkey Kong, will be the first recipient of the Academy's Hall of Fame award. He will receive the award on May 28, the first evening of E3.

Nyko Readies Sony-Licensed Peripherals
Nyko announced Wednesday that its E3 lineup will include a Platinum Series of Sony-licensed peripherals, including TransPad (US$17.99) and the ArcadeMax joystick ($29.99). The company will also show its new Memory Card 72x ($59.95, with 1,080 blocks of memory).

EA on the Ball
World Cup 98 for the Nintendo 64, PlayStation, and PC is out.
Harley Jebens
STB Reports Profits
STB released news of second-quarter 1998 profits (the quarter ended on April 30). Net income was US$2.8 million on net sales of $73.8 million. These numbers are higher than what it reported last year at the same time; Q2 '97 income was $2.4 million on net sales of $48 million.
Gamespot Staff
Sony Awards Top PlayStation Games
Sony honors the top-selling PlayStation games of 1997 in Japan.
Chris Johnston
Breath of Fire III Released
Capcom announced Monday that Breath of Fire III is now available at retail locations nationwide (although many stores did receive the game last week). The third installment of this classic RPG series has an MSRP of US$49.99.
Gamespot Staff
Riot Gets Name Change
First the Riot engine became the LithTech engine. Now, Monolith says the name of the game is undergoing a name change as well. Riot will now be known as SHOGO: Mobile Armor Division.

QBC Is Top-Selling Title
Acclaim Entertainment says NFL Quarterback Club '98 has sold over 900,000 copies worldwide, making it the best-selling N64 sports title ever. The game also recently received the 1997 Nintendo Power award for "Best Sports Game."
Gamespot Staff
NovaLogic's E3 Plans
NL intends to give E3-goers a first look at the fixed-wing aircraft sims F-16 Viper (based on the US Air Force's plane of the same name) and MiG 29 Fulcrum (based on the Russian fighter). NovaLogic will also be debuting the ground-based action game Delta Force at the conference.

g.o.d. Adds Two Titles
Gathering of Developers has added two additional titles to its lineup. The titles are due from Monster Truck Madness 2 developer Terminal Reality. The first is Fly!, a "global flight sim" due later this year; the second is titled Nocturne, a 3D action/adventure game due in late '99.

Gamespot Staff
IGZ Gets Civ II
Microsoft's Internet Gaming Zone is picking up a couple new. MicroProse's Civilization II Multiplayer Gold Edition and X-Com Interceptor are both scheduled to launch this summer on IGZ. The IGZ will provide matchmaking services for gamers wanting to connect with other Civ II or Interceptor players.

Gathering of Developers will publish and distribute Ritual Entertainment's Heavy Metal: F.A.K.K.2. The game is based on the upcoming sequel to the animated flick, Heavy Metal. Both movie and game are due in the late summer.

James Mielke
WON Makes Unreal Easy
The World Opponent Network (WON) has announced the launch of eleven Unreal servers placed at strategic regional areas on the Internet backbone to provide lower latency and better ping times for players worldwide. Owned by Cendant, WON's Unreal servers will feature one-click access and player services through Netscape or Internet Explorer.

The title, developed by Japan's Imagineer Co. Ltd., has shipped. Q64 is the first N64 RPG. THQ will support the launch with network TV and cable buys; those buys include Nickelodeon, NBC, ABC, Fox, MTV, USA, Cartoon Network, and the Warner Bros. channel.

Kain Slips Into '99
Crystal Dynamics informed GameSpot News this morning that Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver for the PlayStation has been pushed back to a January '99 release. Company officials said the reasons were because of the game's ambitious scope and a willingness to not sacrifice quality for a release date.

PlayStation Outsells N64 2.1 to 1
In May, the NPD Group reports, the PlayStation outsold the N64 2.1 to 1. The numbers one and two PlayStation sellers for May, Tekken 3 and Gran Turismo respectively, largely fueled Sony's sales.

Gamespot Staff
Correction
Last week in an interview with Origin general manager Neil Young we stated that the player will not take the role of Casey, as in Wing Commander: Prophecy. Origin has informed us that this is not the case. The player will, in fact, continue the role of Casey in Wing Commander: Secret Ops.
Gamespot Staff
Nintendo Appoints VPs
Nintendo announced several new vice president appointments recently. They are: Peter Junger, VP, national field service; Mike Schachter, VP of Latin America marketing; Jacqualee Story, VP, general counsel; Gail Tilden, VP, product acquisition and development; and Juana Tingdale, VP, licensing.

Moira Muldoon
F-1 World Grand Prix for the N64
Video System has secured the Formula One Administration Limited (FOA) license for its Nintendo 64 racing title, F-1 World Grand Prix. The racer sports one- or two-player simulation, 17 Grand Prix circuits, eleven teams, 22 drivers, and will sell for US$59.95 when it releases on July 27.

Argonaut, developer of the original StarFox and Croc: Legend of Gobbos, has revealed that it is already planning a sequel to its current project, the N64 platform/shooter Buck Bumble. Buck Bumble is planned for release in October of this year through UbiSoft. No release date has been announced for Buck Bumble 2.

AD&D Core Rules Turns Two
Wizards of the Coast Inc., the parent company of TSR Inc., is releasing a second version of its Advanced Dungeons & Dragons role-playing game utility, AD&D Core Rules. The latest version, entitled AD&D Core Rules 2.0, will be available October 1. Among the most-anticipated features is support for the Player's Options and full versions of these books in electronic form.

Chris Johnston
Sony Stock Takes Dive
Sony's less-than-expected financial report yesterday led to the company's stock taking a 440-yen dive (3.37 percent) to 12,600 yen (about US$88.50 at current exchange rates). Though the PlayStation continues to sell well, Sony revised its outlook for the console in Japan, lowering its sales expectations by a million units.

Chris Johnston
Running Wild Officially on 989 Roster
989 Studios officially confirmed news GameSpot posted earlier this week that it will publish Blue Shift's PlayStation racing-on-foot title Running Wild. 989 Studios is the new name of Sony Interactive Studios America. The game was originally due earlier from Universal Interactive. The new release date is late October.

Microsoft and Rainbow Studios say that Motocross Madness, a stunt-driving and motocross racing game, has gone gold and should be in stores by late August. Its biggest feature is its physics engine, which gives gamers additional control of their vehicle during races and stunts.

STB is shipping the new Velocity 4400 multimedia graphics accelerator. The 16MB AGP board, powered by nVidia's RIVA TNT 2D/3D graphics processor, will sell for around US$199.

Micheal Mullen
Ex Ultima Onliners Start Shop
Focusing on multiplayer networked gaming, three ex-Origin staffers have started Wombat Games. Rick Delashmit, lead programmer of UO; Jason Spangler, lead programmer of UO: The Second Age; and Ragnar Scheuermann, programmer on UO and The Second Age, are up and running in Austin, Texas.
Gamespot Staff
Fast Connections On the Rise
Forrester Research is predicting the number of web surfers (and that means online gamers) will increase substantially over the next four years. Whereas there are now 350,000 households with broadband connections to the web, that number should swell to 16 million by 2002.

Ubi's Dreamcast Titles Add Up
France's Ubi Soft revealed today that it now has four Dreamcast titles in development. They are: Speed Busters, a racing title; D-Jump, a 3D action/platformer; Ray Man 2: The Great Escape; and World Grand Prix. GameSpot News was shown Ray Man 2 running on a 3Dfx-equipped PC (at 60fps), and it looked exceptionally beautiful. More Ubi news as we get it.

Sony Online Entertainment rolls out new games on its Station gaming site: Multiplayer and updated single-player versions of Jeopardy! Online and Wheel of Fortune Online; Fantasy War, a turn-based strategy-diplomacy game for two to seven players (in beta); and Internet card game ChronX.

Populous Demo Coming
Bullfrog and EA announced that a demo of Populous: The Beginning will release on Oct. 2. To build up anticipation for the title, Bullfrog has launched a countdown clock on its web site (www.bullfrog.ea.com). The demo will include two single-player levels and one multiplayer level. The full version of the game is due in November.

Pokemon GB Sets Record
Nintendo's newest Game Boy title, Pokemon, has sold more than 200,000 copies over the course of the last two weeks in the US. This makes it the fastest-selling portable game of all time. Considering this is the first of many pieces of Pokemon merchandise to hit US shores...it looks like the Teletubbies are on their way out.

Patch for Axis and Allies
Hasbro Interactive released today a patch that "addresses issues such as players' ability to land planes on aircraft carriers, placing purchased ships on the game board, various multiplayer game crashes and sending messages." Find the patch at www.axisandallies.com.

Metal Gear Today
One of the most anticipated PlayStation games of 1998, Metal Gear Solid, begins arriving in stores today. A quick call to the local Electronics Boutique and/or Babbage's confirmed that they are indeed expecting them today but not until late afternoon or evening.
Chris Johnston
The Zone's Fighting Ants
Ants, a free Internet-based multiplayer strategy game, is up and running on the MSN Gaming Zone (www.zone.com). Gamers control ants in a miniature world with all the basics - giant sodas and monstrous Jell-O included. The object is to get as much of the food back to your anthill as you can, while battling up to three other players.

Insider tips from the Southland indicate Apogee-3D Realms is close to naming a replacement for Prey project leader Paul Schuytema who left the team this week. The announcement will occur next week - and will likely be someone "on loan" from another company.
Gamespot Staff
Metal Gear Gears Up
TV and magazine ads, in-store merchandise give-aways for purchasers, in-store sampling, direct mail promotions, PlayStation hardware pack-ins and more demo giveaways will preceed and accompany Konami's upcoming Metal Gear Solid release. The whole promotional campaign will cost the companies a total of US$8 million. But hey, we're worth it.

Eidos is rumored to have entertained a decision-making threesome from ION Storm in its San Francisco offices recently. The two sides are still said to be on the path toward a revitalized (ah-hem) relationship and are very close to finalizing a deal. More details as we get them.

Broderbund Moves
Broderbund president and CEO, Bill McDonagh, will leave the company effective March 31, 1998, the company announced Friday. McDonagh's duties will be assumed by CFO Joe Durrett and a group of newly appointed vice presidents that consists of J. Mark Hattendorf, Alma Rodoni, and Dan Steever.

Harley Jebens
Titanium Trilogy Readied
MechWarrior 2 or MechWarrior 2: Mercenaries owners interested in picking up the upcoming MechWarrior 2: Titanium Trilogy (featuring those two titles bundled with MechWarrior 2: Ghost Bear's Legacy) will be eligible for a US$15 to $25 rebate on the title. Owners of one of the two MW titles will get $15 back from Activision; owners of both MW2 and Mercenaries will get $25 back. The deal runs from March 15 through Nov. 30. The Titanium Trilogy is scheduled to be released on March 16.

Micheal Mullen
Take 2's New CFO
Take 2 Interactive has a new chief financial officer. Anthony R. Williams, formerly of Acclaim Entertainment, has been appointed to that post, the company announced. Williams spent ten years at Acclaim, serving as the company's director of finance and operations, chief financial officer, and, most recently, vice president of mergers and acquisitions.

Rebecca Anderson
Hasbro in Jeopardy
Hasbro Interactive announced today that it has picked up the license to produce CD-ROM and Sony PlayStation versions of the TV game shows Jeopardy and Wheel of Fortune. The agreement was made with Sony Signatures, the Agent for Columbia TriStar Television, which owns the rights to those two game shows. Games based on both properties will be released this fall.

Parasite Eve Delay
Square's marquee title Parasite Eve has encountered a delay. The game's new release is slated for March 29 - about a week later than previously expected. Square announced that the game is compatible with the PlayStation analog controller (but will not sport any force feedback).

Chris Johnston
Bronx and Touring Car Ship
Sega Entertainment announced today it's releasing its popular arcade fighting game Last Bronx and racing title Sega Touring Car Championship on the PC. Both games sport features unique to the PC versions - network play, force feedback, hi-res 3D graphics, and hidden elements such as extra cars and weapons (including a frozen tuna in Last Bronx). Both games shipped Thursday.

Harley Jebens
Nintendo Joystick To Shake
Primax announced that it's entered an agreement with Laral Group LLC,worldwide licensee of the Nintendo brand for PC peripherals, to use Immersion's I-Force 2.0 force feedback technology in the next iteration of its joystick. The joystick should ship sometime before year's end. No pricing information is currently available.

Spearhead Goes to IMagic
Interactive Magic just signed on Zombie Interactive's tank sim Spearhead, a title Zombie showed at last year's E3, and will publish the game this September. IMagic and Zombie will now codevelop the property. IMagic is also planning an add-on to Seven Kingdoms (expect three new kingdoms and loads of additional multiplayer options).

Alan Dunkin
ASC Sets Grand Theft Auto Release
ASC announced Tuesday that GTA for the PC will hit stores on March 24. The PlayStation version will follow on April 15 (tax day - think of it as a good way to take out your frustrations). ASC is not shying away from the potentially controversial nature of the title; rather, it's even boasting the more notorious features - banned in Brazil, etc. - in Tuesday's announcement.
Chris Johnston

Yoshi's Journey Almost Complete
Reports from many retailers today place Nintendo's Yoshi's Story in stores as early as Tuesday. Be sure to call ahead to see if your local store has received its copy. Some stores, like Best Buy, are offering free gifts if you buy the game from them - look for Yoshi T-shirts given the first 50 people that purchase the game at stores on Wednesday.

Alan Dunkin
Star Control 4 Renamed
Accolade's fourth installment in the Star Control series won't bear that name any longer. It will now be called StarCon. The new game will feature third-person three-dimensional space combat, two- to eight-player cooperative or competitive deathmatches on LANs or TCP/IP, and three-dimensional polygonal texture-mapped graphics. StarCon will be available in the fall.
Alan Dunkin
EA's Road Rash 3D on Track
Road Rash 3D's release date has not slipped to May, an EA spokeswoman confirmed on Monday. Recently, rumors that the action biking game was going to be delayed have been surfacing across the Web. All appears to be well, and the game is still slated for a March release.

Harley Jebens
Midway Spin-Off A Go
WMS Industries announced Wednesday that its planned spin-off of 86.7 percent of its interest in Midway Games has been approved by the IRS. WMS stockholders will receive 1.2 shares of Midway common stock for each share of WMS stock owned as of April 6, 1998.

Atari Sale Official
Friday, JTS Corp. officially announced that it is indeed selling off all its Atari assets, gained through the company's merger with Atari in 1996, to Hasbro for US$5 million in cash. It's expected that Hasbro will make an official announcement regarding the purchase on Monday.

Interstate ‘76 Film Rights Sold
In news that's a few weeks old in Hollywood but may be new to gamers, the film option to Activision's Interstate '76 was picked up by John Davis Productions. The company plans to make the film for Fox Studios. Apart from Davis, whose other production credits include the Predator series and Waterworld, there are no names attached to the project.

Righteous 3D owners need only establish proof of purchase and then submit their name to a contest run off from Orchid's Web site. Winners get US$100 off the price of a new Righteous 3D II. For more information, go to http://www.orchid.com/.

Powerboat Racing Drifts Onto Shelves
VR Sports announced today that it has shipped Powerboat Racing for the PlayStation and Windows 95. With a plethora of boats to choose from, eight courses, and a shadow boat feature, the title promises to offer realistic boat racing action. The Win95 version supports four-player split-screen and six-player network play.
Chris Johnston
Powerboat Racing Drifts Onto Shelves
VR Sports announced today that it has shipped Powerboat Racing for the PlayStation and Windows 95. With a plethora of boats to choose from, eight courses, and a shadow boat feature, the title promises to offer realistic boat racing action. The Win95 version supports four-player split-screen and six-player network play.

MicroProse Vote Nears
Shareholders will vote next month on a 1-for-5 reverse stock split designed to help the company comply with NASDAQ listing requirements. MicroProse CEO Steve Race says the reverse split will have no effect on shareholders' investment values but is necessary to insure that the company remain a NASDAQ-traded company.

Japan's Nikkei Shinbun recently reported that Square's Final Fantasy VII for the PC will get a June 25 release in North America, Europe, and Australia. Micheal Mullen
Matrox's Next Step: MGA-G200
Matrox ups the ante in the video card war with its MGA-200, a 128-bit dual-bus 2D/3D accelerator with AGP 2X support. The card is capable of utilizing up to 16MB of SGRAM with a 250MHz RAMDAC. Look for it around June or July. An 8MB model should run around US$170.

Harley Jebens
Matrox G100 Cancelled
Matrox has axed its Marvel G100 graphics card (it was based on the company's low-end MGA-G100 graphics chip). The company cited feedback from channel developers more interested in a "no compromise" solution attainable from the company's higher 2D/3D performance G200 chipset.

IDSA Says Gaming Worth US$16 Billion
The Interactive Digital Software Association says that in addition to the US$5.6 billion generated from sales of PC and console titles in the US during 1997, other aspects of the game business like research, payroll, packaging, printing, talent, and equipment manufacturing brings the total economic activity to a grand total of $16 billion.
Gamespot Staff
IDSA Says Gaming Worth US$16 Billion
The Interactive Digital Software Association says that in addition to the US$5.6 billion generated from sales of PC and console titles in the US during 1997, other aspects of the game business like research, payroll, packaging, printing, talent, and equipment manufacturing brings the total economic activity to a grand total of $16 billion.

Dual Shock Hits US
The US version of Sony's Dual Shock hit stores on Wednesday. The controller sells for around US$29.99. The pad is available in only the standard gray color instead of the 3+ colors available in Japan. Games that support the Dual Shock currently include Dead Or Alive, Gran Turismo, and Tekken 3.

Gamespot Staff
Electronic Arts on a Roll
Revenues for the country's largest game software company keep on growing. In the fourth quarter ending March 31, 1998, EA revs jumped 31 percent to US$204 million and net income increased 45 percent to $15.3 million. For the year ending March 31, revs were $908.8 million (up 35 percent ) and net income jumped 41 percent to $72.6 million. New NASCAR, Tiger Woods, and World Championship Wrestling licenses could propel EA revenues even higher.
Gamespot Staff

MicroProse's first-person action-adventure game Star Trek: First Contact, which was to utilize the Unreal engine, has been cancelled. Two other Star Trek games in production, Klingon Honor Guard and Birth of the Federation, remain in development.

Chris Johnston
Games for Good Sell Out
Talk about sell-through. The Games for Good charity event, which benefits the Starbright Foundation's efforts to aid seriously ill children, has sold out its E3 dinner and will likely raise about US$350,000. The E3 event is a silent auction - an event stocked with goods and services from dozens of companies including Berkeley Systems, Microsoft's Games Group, Sierra On-Line, SouthPeak Interactive, and GameSpot.
Gamespot Staff
Games for Good Sell Out
Talk about sell-through. The Games for Good charity event, which benefits the Starbright Foundation's efforts to aid seriously ill children, has sold out its E3 dinner and will likely raise about US$350,000. The E3 event is a silent auction - an event stocked with goods and services from dozens of companies including Berkeley Systems, Microsoft's Games Group, Sierra On-Line, SouthPeak Interactive, and GameSpot.

E3 Attracts Over 41,000
E3 proved to be a big success this year, attracting 41,300 people from 80 countries to Atlanta, Ga. This figure is an 11 percent rise in attendance from last year. Next year the show moves back to Los Angeles and will run from May 13-15. Mark your calendars!

Harley Jebens
ThrustMaster Cuts Back
ThrustMaster will reduce its worldwide workforce to 90 people, a thirty percent cut. The reduction is due in part to "soft" retail sales in the first half of the fiscal year. Revenue for the second quarter will likely fall short of analysts' predictions, the company said.

Pop Top Software is looking for game feature ideas for its upcoming strategy game Railroad Tycoon II. The five winners in the "Doh, Why Didn't I Think Of That" contest will receive one of the actual HO gauge train models used in the game, a free copy of the game when it comes out, and their name in the credits. Hit www.poptop.com/contest.htm for details.

Midway Nabs Manhattan Project
Inside sources have informed GameSpot News that Midway will be publishing Radical Entertainment's Manhattan Project (working title) the first quarter of next year. First seen in the pages of Electronic Gaming Monthly several months back, the multiplayer PlayStation title resembles a wicked version of Konami's Poy Poy. Midway is currently publishing Radical's Jackie Chan's Stuntmaster.

GT Looks to Gain Money
GT Interactive is looking to raise US$100 million. And it's hoping to do it through an issue to institutional investors of "Senior Subordinated Notes due in 2005." The company plans to use that $100 million primarily to repay some of the company debt and to fund future acquisitions and operations.

Curt Feldman
Battlecruiser Publisher
Interplay will be publishing and distributing Battlecruiser 3000AD v2.0, according to the title's creator, Derek Smart. The title will be published under Interplay's affiliated title program, which, Smart says, means "3000AD Inc. [Smart's company] retains development control and tech support of the title." BC30000AD v2.0 is expected at retail in late '98.

Two Classics Saturn Bound
Two classic Mega Drive and Genesis titles are planned for the Saturn. On October 15, Sega plans on releasing a new title in the Sega Ages series. The game will feature Mickey Mouse: Castle of Illusion and Donald Duck: Quack Shot. Gamers will have to content themselves with the import version of this CD as the chances of a US release are mighty slim. The game will carry a 4,800 yen price in Japan.

Blizzard on the Block
Cendant Corp. has hired Credit Suisse First Boston to put together the sale of Cendant's consumer software division. That division includes Starcraft publisher Blizzard Entertainment, and Sierra On-line. The Wall Street Journal puts annual revenues of the division at US$650 million.

Interplay Productions has hired a director of direct sales whose agenda will include beefing up Interplay's already existing online sales operation. Diane Forsman is the new hire. Interplaystore.com should be up and running before the end of the year.

James Mielke
Toys 'R' Us Earnings Go Down
Toys "R" Us reported a second-quarter earnings drop of more than 60 percent from last year. The drop was attributed to weak sales of video games, virtual pets, dolls, and action figures - and the fact that there were no blockbuster toys like last year's Star Wars figures to boost sales.
Gamespot Staff
Toys 'R' Us Earnings Go Down
Toys "R" Us reported a second-quarter earnings drop of more than 60 percent from last year. The drop was attributed to weak sales of video games, virtual pets, dolls, and action figures - and the fact that there were no blockbuster toys like last year's Star Wars figures to boost sales.

One down, one to go. One million, that is. Midway games says it has completed the repurchase of 1,000,000 shares of common stock and will soon repurchase an additional 1,000,000 shares. Midway currently has 37,500,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

Chris Johnston
Shogo: MAD Nearing Gold
Monolith's CEO Jason Hall indicated Monday that their anticipated anime-based first-person action game Shogo: MAD was near to mastering, anywhere between "five minutes and 72 hours" from now. Hall also noted that the game, to be self published by Monolith, will likely in limited supply for quite some time. Shogo: MAD is due around October 19.

Two Hires for Dreamcast Team
Sega of America has hired Stephen Ackroyd and Jared Rosen to be part of its Dreamcast dream team. Ackroyd assumes the role of VP and general manager of business development, overseeing Sega's network gaming and e-commerce business model. Rosen was named director of research and development.

Micheal Mullen
NFS III Update
EA announced the release of the PC version of the PlayStation racing title Need for Speed III: Hot Pursuit. The PlayStation version of the game was released earlier this year. The PC version features an expanded "chase or be chased" hot pursuit mode, 3D graphics, multiplayer support, and five more cars than the PlayStation version - 13 cars total.
Gamespot Staff
Kesmai in German Partnership
Kesmai has signed a strategic comarketing partnership with HandMade SoftWare, a South African software and Internet solutions company, that will bring Kesmai's GameStorm service to that country. The agreement will see a cobranded GameStorm domain, which HandMade will create and host.
Gamespot Staff
Fighter Ace Tournament Starting
Route 66, the new 16-team six-player team tournament event for Microsoft's online flight simulation Fighter Ace, will be starting up on Thursday and Friday - with plenty of prizes. It will be first-come first-served, so interested participants should head to the Internet Gaming Zone (www.zone.com) for more information.

Ron Dulin
RedJack Due From THQ
THQ has released its RedJack: Revenge of the Brethren, an action-adventure game for both the PC and Mac. Developed by CyberFlix, the Titanic: Adventure Out of Time company, RedJack puts gamers in the shoes of a shipmate on the trail of buried pirate treasure. The game boasts feature film-styled animation and an MSRP of US$39.95.

Alan Dunkin
Toy 'R' Us Drops in Size
The New Jersey-based toy store giant just got a little smaller. It will be closing 59 underperforming stores (mostly in Europe), laying off close to 3,000 employees, and redesigning stores to emphasize electronics and apparel. The redesigned stores will also stock larger selections of computer and console games.
Gamespot Staff
Toy 'R' Us Drops in Size
The New Jersey-based toy store giant just got a little smaller. It will be closing 59 underperforming stores (mostly in Europe), laying off close to 3,000 employees, and redesigning stores to emphasize electronics and apparel. The redesigned stores will also stock larger selections of computer and console games.
Gamespot Staff
Fast 50 Includes Gamers
Activision and THQ made the list of fastest-growing technology companies in the LA area. The 1998 Los Angeles Technology Fast 50 lineup put Activision at number 27 with 310-percent growth over the past five years and THQ at number 43 with 138-percent growth.
Gamespot Staff
Fast 50 Includes Gamers
Activision and THQ made the list of fastest-growing technology companies in the LA area. The 1998 Los Angeles Technology Fast 50 lineup put Activision at number 27 with 310-percent growth over the past five years and THQ at number 43 with 138-percent growth.

Microsoft Sponsors Supercross
Microsoft will be the exclusive PC entertainment sponsor for the US Open of Supercross (USSX), the world's largest Supercross event to be held at the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas on Oct. 10-11. Attendees will get to swing over and take Motocross Madness for a spin and win prizes. No mud throwing allowed (unless you lose).

PaintBrawl Due From Head Games
Head Games ships paint ball sim Sheridan's Extreme PaintBrawl this week. Sheridan Paintball is an air gun manufacturer. The title features five playing fields and eight paint guns. The single- and multiplayer game has an MSRP of US$19.99.

We Got Game
Those wonderful folks who brought us E3 say: gamers, buckle up! A recent IDSA study says the PC and console industry experienced 70 percent growth in the first half of 1998, homes with consoles has grown from 6 million in 1996 to an estimated 27 - 30 million by the end of 98, and 45 percent of all homes now pack at least one PC.
Gamespot Staff
We Got Game
Those wonderful folks who brought us E3 say: gamers, buckle up! A recent IDSA study says the PC and console industry experienced 70 percent growth in the first half of 1998, homes with consoles has grown from 6 million in 1996 to an estimated 27 - 30 million by the end of 98, and 45 percent of all homes now pack at least one PC.

Alan Dunkin
Thrill Kill Completely Dead
After repeated inquiries from readers, we contacted Electronic Arts to reconfirm the status of Thrill Kill. The company reiterated that the PlayStation title has been cancelled and will not be published. When asked if the title would be sold to another publisher, EA responded that Thrill Kill would not. That's it folks - Thrill Kill RIP.

Activision Alert
The company's web site will be down (but not out) for a week beginning October 5. A network upgrade to increase services and deliver more efficient downloads during the high-traffic times of the holidays is the goal. For the days of Oct 5-11, the Activision site will be limited to a single web page for all Activision services.

The company's web site will be down (but not out) for a week beginning October 5. A network upgrade to increase services and deliver more efficient downloads during the high-traffic times of the holidays is the goal. Games Trader Deal Completed
Shareholders of Xencet Investments have approved that company's acquisition of Games Trader Inc., a supplier of previously played Nintendo, Sony, and Sega video games to retail outlets in the US and Canada. The deal could be worth US$7.5 million or more.

Creative Labs and Aureal: Together Again
3D sound rivals, Creative Labs and Aureal Semiconductor, find themselves in court again. This time Creative is accusing Aureal of false advertising - and false statements Aureal made about Creative's Sound Blaster Live! audio card. The lawsuit was filed Wednesday. There is a separate patent case pending that Creative brought against Aureal in February.

Creative Labs announced that it has chopped the price for its 3DBlaster Voodoo2 line of cards. The 12MB version will sell for US$149.99 after a $50 rebate, and the 8MB version will sell for $79.99 after a $30 mail-in rebate.

SouthPeak Soldiers On
The upcoming Warner feature film Soldier (starring Kurt Russell) will be made into a PC and PlayStation title by Gigawatt Studios for SouthPeak Interactive. A summer '99 PC release will precede a PlayStation game in the fall.
Gamespot Staff
Hasbro's Online Slingo
Hasbro Interactive has taken popular America Online title Slingo and put it on a CD. Slingo first appeared on AOL back in October 1996 and has consistently remained in the number one slot as most popular online game. The CD-ROM game offers the classic Slingo gameplay along with four new variations. The Windows 95/98 game is selling for US$19.95.

Gamespot Staff
Myth II Rounds Out Support
What hardware will Myth II support? Bungie moves to support almost everything you can throw at it.
Micheal Mullen
Brood War Beta On The Loose
The lucky few beta testers start banging on the beta beginning today.
Curt Feldman
Metal Gear Racks Up Sales
According to Konami, its latest PlayStation title, Metal Gear Solid sold 350,000 units over the weekend. Sony is helping Konami to market the title, which it believes is a hardware-seller for the holiday season. Ads for the title will run through Christmas.
Gamespot Staff
Pikachu Comes to Stores
The virtual pet-like pedometer game Pokemon Pikachu will make its way to stores next Monday (Nov. 2). The game, which straps to either a belt or can be fashioned into a necklace, originated in Japan and stars Nintendo's most popular (and cute) Pokemon Pikachu.
Gamespot Staff
PC Data Hit List for September
September's lineup of top-selling games puts Deer Hunter back on top - with Clancy's thriller right behind.
Gamespot Staff
Montezuma's Return Ships
GT Interactive and WizardWorks have announced that Montezuma's Return has shipped to retailers for US$19.99. The Windows 95/98 3D action/adventure title picks up where the classic Montezuma's Revenge left off as Max Montezuma seeks to restore the desecrated tomb of his legendary ancestor.
Gamespot Staff
New N64 Release Day
Today, F-Zero X and WCW Revenge arrive in stores for the Nintendo 64. F-Zero X is the 64-bit update to Nintendo's original futuristic racing title, and THQ's WCW Revenge, of course, is a wrestling title in the mega-popular line of WCW games.
Gamespot Staff
Memory Cards With Personality
Lara Croft leads the list of character-adorned memory cards.
Gamespot Staff
Gravis Stings Laptop Gamers
Playing games on a laptop can be difficult without a controller. Gravis fixes the problem.
Micheal Mullen
Sony Kicks Off With The 49ers
Sony gets the San Francisco 49ers off the field and into head-to-head Gran Turismo competition.
Game Boy Color Gets Pushed Up
Nintendo's release of Game Boy Color gets pushed up by about a week, but where's Wario?
Chris Johnston
Bungie Part of the Inc. 500
Myth and Myth II publisher Bungie Software joined 499 other companies selected by Inc. magazine as the 500 fastest growing private corporations in the US. Bungie ranked at number 101. Bungie says its income jumped 2,228 percent from 1993 to 1997.
Gamespot Staff
Play the Game, Read the Book
The official novelization of Nintendo's upcoming The Legend of Zelda is due in November.
Gamespot Staff
Gamers Quest for Hunting, Shooting Games Answered
Activision adds to its already impressive lineup of gamer, hunter, shooter titles (Cabela's Big Game Hunter is theirs) this week with the release of Head Games-developed Remington Top Shot, a trap, skeet, police-style shooting title that tests gamers' aiming skills.
Gamespot Staff
Today's Releases
Ripcord Games' add-on for SpecOps, Ranger Team Bravo, is now available in stores for October 26, 1998. Digital Integration Design's Total Air War should also be hitting stores starting Monday.

Gamer interest is at a peak - so Raven has swooped in to tweak the demo to near perfection.

Yutaka Ohbuchi
Lower Priced GB Pocket
Nintendo Co. Ltd. announced Friday that beginning November 14, the Game Boy Pocket will be priced at 3,800 yen (about $32). Nintendo of America told GameSpot News today that it has no plans at this time to change the price of the standard Game Boy Pocket in the US.

Everyone's talking about the Heretic II demo. We dispel some of the rumors rampant of the Web.

Hasbro Interactive's Centipede 3D is hitting stores October 23. GameSpot News has also received word that Interplay's Fallout 2 and LucasArts' Grim Fandango have both been mastered and should be hitting stores soon.

Midway Sets Up 'Net Shop
Midway has set up an online store via its web site. Four multiplatform titles are available for purchase: NFL Blitz, MK4, Gex Enter the Gecko, and Rampage World Tour. More will be added by Christmas and in 1999.
Gamespot Staff
Activision Sets Apocalypse Date
Activision's long-awaited, much-delayed PlayStation action title Apocalypse will finally be available in stores on November 17. You take on the role of Trey Kincaid (played by Bruce Willis) in a knock-down, drag out war against the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

The Rise of Rome is released and should hit full distribution by Nov. 5.

SouthPeak Entertainment will distribute Blue Byte Software's upcoming multiplayer RTS title, Settlers III, to the North American market this November. A DVD-ROM version is lined up for early '99.

Strang Named Group Publisher
The Ziff-Davis Video Game Group - comprised of Electronic Gaming Monthly, Expert Gamer, and the Official US PlayStation Magazine - has a new leader. Dale Strang was named group publisher of the Video Game Group Tuesday. He relinquishes his position as publisher of Ziff's Computer Gaming World.

Gamespot Staff
Voodoo2 On The Cheap
Guillemot has announced that it has lowered the price of its Voodoo2-based 12MB board - the Maxi Gamer 3D2 to only US$99.00 (after a $30 mail-in rebate). Gamers looking for more power can buy two boards in SLI mode for only $199.99. Orders can be placed through Guillemot's web site, Fry's, Micro Center, Aventure Electronic or Business Depot.

Berkeley's Big Idea

Harley Jebens
Me President, You Intern
2AM Games will soon launch an online game it's calling Capitol Affairs. Gamers choose the role of President, Republicans, Democrats, the CIA, or the media - what, no interns? - and try to either get into trouble or stay out of it. As always, the choice is yours. Other 2AM games include Total War and The Invisible Hand (www.2am.com).
Gamespot Staff
GT Yanks Rebel Moon
Fenris Wolf's Theo Beale tells GameSpot News his work in progress, Rebel Moon Revolution, has lost the support of GT Interactive. Beale says he's already been talking to other publishers about the first-person shooter. We'll have to wait and see if the game makes it to retailers for the holidays as previously expected. A GT spokesperson would not confirm the news.

Acclaim has shipped NFL Quarterback Club '99 for the N64. The new title has huddled together several features including a new 3D engine, NFL commentators Mike Patrick and Randy Cross, over 45 minutes of speech (five times more than the last game) and the endorsement by NFL MVP Brett Favre.

Harley Jebens
Eidos' Done Deal
Eidos has completed its acquisition of Crystal Dynamics. The deal, announced in September, cost Eidos approximately US$47.5 million. Crystal D games GEX III Deep Cover Gecko, Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver, Akuji the Heartless, and The Unholy War will now be brought to you by Eidos.

Sources close to Sierra have informed GameSpot News that Valve's Half-Life has finally gone gold. Since there hasn't been official word yet - the title's actual release date is unknown but it looks like it will indeed be on gamers' hard drives for Thanksgiving (Nov. 26 for all you non-US gamers).

Electronic Arts says X Games Pro Boarder for the PC has gone gold and should be on shelves Nov. 23. The title features nine levels and music from bands like the Foo Fighters, Rancid, and Pennywise.

Activision announced that it has lowered the price of its auto-combat title Vigilante 8 for the PlayStation. The special holiday price, US$29.99, is available at EB, Babbages, Software Etc, Best Buy, Toys "R" Us, Kay Bee Toys, and Circuit City.

Two-player puzzler Hexcite for the Game Boy Color is due from Rayman-publisher Ubi Soft next month. The one- or two-person title will be among the first group of GBC games. Hexcite will be compatible with the original Game Boy as well.

Talonsoft has announced that West Front, its tactical-level wargame of warfare in Western Europe in 1944-45, is currently in replication and should hit store shelves late next week. The game utilizes the same engine, albeit with many improvements, that was used in East Front.

Jane's WWII Fighters has gone gold and is due for an on-time arrival in retail stores next week. A detailed mission editor and eight-player multiplayer are part of the 3D package from Jane's.

Micheal Mullen
Cyberstrike 2 Out
Sony's 989 Studios has released its online action-strategy title Cyberstrike 2. Cyberstrike 2's gameplay takes place in post-apocalyptic city landscapes. The game features single-player mode, with 50 missions, and a multi-player mode where up to 32 players can compete at one time.
Gamespot Staff
Berkeley Satisfies With Jack Sports
Berkeley Systems and M&M/Mars have teamed up to bring You Don't Know Jack Sports to Snickers eaters everywhere. From now until March 9, 1999, 100 million The Big One Snickers bars will come with various sports questions from the title.

Square Sets a Date for VIII
TOKYO - Square has announced the release date for its upcoming PlayStation RPG, Final Fantasy VIII. The game will be released February 11 in Japan for 7800 yen (about US$64). The game will be four discs in length (one more than VII).

Harley Jebens
Ackley Announces New Venture
Rumored for about the past week and made official by an announcement on Monday, Jonathan Ackley and his wife Casey Donahue Ackley have started their own Northern California dev house, Stargazy Studios. Both are LucaArts alum. Jonathan is known among gamers as the codesigner and project leader of LucasArts' The Curse of Monkey Island.
Gamespot Staff
Acclaim Ties Up Australia
Acclaim picks up a direct distribution channel in Australia with its purchase of Melbourne's Digital Leisure distribution op. Given that foreign markets account for close to 40 percent of game sales for the Glen Cove, NY-based Acclaim Entertainment, the move that solidifies market presence makes good sense.

MX300 Still on Target
A rumor on the Web claims Diamond's Monster Sound MX300 is being pushed back to late December or early 1999 because of unresolved driver issues. While we can confirm that the last beta drivers we received do have some serious problems, Diamond says that the sound board will ship later in November.

Gamespot Staff
Test Drive 5 Ships
Accolade ships Test Drive 5, its muscle-car racing sim, today. The game features more than 28 licensed cars that can be raced (through traffic, chased by police) in 18 real-world locations. The game features a new 3D engine developed by The Pitbull Syndicate. The PlayStation version of the game shipped in October.

Buck Busts Onto TV
Ubi Soft announced Tuesday that the star of its upcoming N64 title Buck Bumble will burst onto the airwaves November 27 in an advertising campaign promoting the game's release. The two-week national TV campaign will target the game's 12-17 age group. Buck Bumble is scheduled to arrive in stores later this week.
Gamespot Staff
ASC Hits the Fast 500
ASC Games proudly announced that it has been named to Deloitte & Touche's Fast 500 Program, a ranking of the fastest-growing US technology companies, with 894-percent revenue growth from 1993-1997. The company is also the seventh-fastest-growing tech company in the Connecticut Technology Council's Fast 50.

Populous Begins
Bullfrog and EA have announced the release of Populous: The Beginning for Windows 95/98. Players become the Shaman, a priestess who uses her powers to protect and lead her tribe of worshippers by giving them the ability to build, shape land, and build armies. The title sells for US$49.99, and a PlayStation version of the title is expected next year.

Microsoft Feels the Force
Microsoft released its Sidewinder Force Feedback Wheel, designed to provide an authentic and realistic driving feel. The wheel also comes with slip-resistant pedals and two games: CART Precision Racing and Monster Truck Madness 2. The Sidewinder Force Feedback Wheel will retail for about US$210.

Blood II Bleeds Out to Retailers
Monolith Productions announced that Blood II: The Chosen has been released to retailers. The title, built upon the company's LithTech engine, offers 40 levels, 14 'Bloodbath' levels, and support for up to 32 simultaneous players.

Zelda, Zelda, Zelda
Enjoy some Zelda tonight folks. If you still have not gotten a copy, keep looking - they are out there. We found some at a local Comp USA store long after the toy stores and game stores were sold out (some of which only received half their shipment). And now it's time to leave and play our copy... enjoy!
Gamespot Staff
THQ Ships Rugrats Game Boy Game
Shipping to stores today is THQ's Game Boy title based on Nickelodeon's successful Rugrats series. Based on The Rugrats Movie, the game will retail for US$29.99 and follows the exploits of Tommy, Dil, Chuckie, and the Reptar Wagon.

Chris Johnston
Knocking Out a Collectable
EA Sports announced Tuesday that Knockout Kings (now shipping) will come in one of five collectable CDs with special artwork. The art features each of the four exclusive boxers in the game and a fifth design with all four fighting on it. The game retails for about US$45.

Yutaka Ohbuchi
It's a Bug's Life, Baby
While the film will open Wednesday, SCEA announced Tuesday that the PlayStation title based on the movie is making its way to stores. Developed by Travellers Tales, this 3D adventure game features cutscenes from the film and puts you in the role of Flik, the main character in the movie, as he tries to save Ant Island from the grasshoppers.

Zelda Winner Steps Forward
The winner of our Zelda Watch contest this past weekend was Noppharat Nuangchamnong of Portland, OR. He was the first person to e-mail us the location of a store in Oregon selling Zelda that we verified Monday morning. Congrats Noppharat!
Gamespot Staff
VR Sports Gives it Up
Interplay will swap out the moniker of its sports division - renaming it from VR Sports to Interplay Sports and giving the newly named division its own Web site, at www.interplaysports.com.
Gamespot Staff
Now Shipping
989 Studios' translation of Enix's PlayStation dance and rhythm action game, Bust A Groove, has shipped to retailers. Psygnosis' PlayStation puzzle action title Roll Away has also shipped. Both are just in time for Friday, Nov. 27, traditionally known as the busiest shopping day of the year.
Gamespot Staff
THQ Opens Web Storefront
THQ has announced that its new web site is open for business-literally. Through the site, gamers can now browse information on the company's titles, download video clips, chat, purchase games, or, if they're market-savvy, look at THQ's stock through an updating ticker. The site is located at www.thq.com.

Rogue Squadron 3D Releases
LucasArts' Star Wars:Rogue Squadron 3D for 3D accelerated PCs is out. Players take on the Empire once again in one of four vehicles (X, Y, A, and V wings). Since the title takes place between the original Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back, gamers will be able to fly missions on several of the planets from those two movies.

Chris Johnston
Capcom Brings MSH vs. SF to the PlayStation
Capcom will release Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter for the PlayStation in February '99. Unfortunately, this translation of the arcade game and popular Saturn title will be missing the tag-team mode from the original. In its place is a crossover mode that allows tag-team play with two players playing with the same two characters on both teams.
Gamespot Staff
A Bug's Life Infests Game Boy Color
THQ has shipped its Game Boy Color title based on Disney/Pixar's latest movie A Bug's Life. Compatible with all versions of the Game Boy, A Bug's Life follows Flik, the main character of the movie, through his quest to save his ant colony from a pack of grasshopper bullies. A Bug's Life retails for around US$29.95.

Gamespot Staff
New Sin Patch on CD
Don't want to deal with downloading the big Sin patch? Well, Activision apparently understands that and is offering a CD with the Sin update v1.01 along with a bonus deathmatch level. All you need is a full copy of the game, and you'll need to send an e-mail with your address to sinupdate@activision.com.
Gamespot Staff
Ubi Soft Releases S.C.A.R.S.
Ubi Soft has released its arcade racing meets animal kingdom title, S.C.A.R.S. (Super Computer Animal Racing Simulation), for the PC, PlayStation, and Nintendo 64. The PC version supports Glide, Direct3D, and force feedback controllers and sells for US$19.99.
Gamespot Staff
Mplayer Deals in Death
Mplayer, Eidos, and ION Storm are teaming up for a Daikatana deathmatch competition that will see John Romero defend his game. The Mplayer site has details. After one month of online play, finalists will be flown down to Texas to compete face-to-face with Romero. See mplayer.com for details.

America Online has added Kesmai's Air Warrior III to its Games Channel. The latest in Kesmai's now decade-old series of World War II combat sims features faithful reenactments of World War II campaigns, 3D-acceleration support, and real-time voice communications.

Upland Game Hunter Due
Head Games' Upland Game Hunter, a hunting sim it developed with gun-maker Remington, is ready for action. Virtual hunters can go after pheasant, quail, grouse, and seven other upland game birds using six shotguns (Remington shotguns, naturally). The game also sports a virtual Remington catalog and a firearm safety guide.

The SingleTrac Streak
SingleTrac's latest title, Streak, a racing game where players are situated on hoverboard-type GEMBlades, has been released nationwide. GT Interactive is supporting the title with extensive print, online, and cross-promotion campaigns. The game is available now for US$49.95.
Gamespot Staff
Taito Derailment
TOKYO - Taito announced today that it was delaying the PlayStation version of its ultrapopular train simulation Densha de GO! 2 from its planned December 17 release. It is now due March 18. The announcement caused Taito stock to drop 2,000 yen today on the Nikkei.

Loyd Case
ION Drops Another
Another ION staffer has taken that last elevator ride down from the company's top-floor perch. Ion Storm artist Ken Scott has left ION and joined id Software. While there has been much ado about ION losing staff, little news has surfaced about who's minding the store. More ION news as we get it.

Sega Tries Humor to Move DC
TOKYO - Sega biggie endures faux fall from grace - all in the effort to sell more Dreamcasts. Do Japanese gamers get the joke?
Yutaka Ohbuchi
Tribes Close to Gold
Sources close to Sierra say that Starsiege Tribes will be hitting gold by week's end. The Dynamix-developed 3D shooter has been built on the same engine as Starsiege. As soon as we hear official word, we'll let you know when to expect the title.
Gamespot Staff
Wizardry Archive Released
Interplay and Sirtech are releasing the Ultimate Wizardry Archives, which bundles all the games to date in the Wizardry role-playing game series, from Proving Grounds of the Mad Overlord through to Wizardry Gold, the latest in the Wizardry line. The collection will retail for US$29.95.
Gamespot Staff
TEN Maxes Out
Calling this "the biggest news since launching the PGL," TEN has gone public with its widespread deals with AltaVista, Excite, GeoCities, Infoseek, Netscape, Prodigy, WebCrawler, and other web sites to provide TEN-branded online playing fields of TEN's titles. TEN claims it now reaches over 60 percent of all US-based Web users.
Gamespot Staff
3Dfx To Acquire STB
$141 million stock swap signals 3Dfx's expansion. 3Dfx sees greater control, higher profits. Competitor nVidia calls the move desperate.
Micheal Mullen

Looking for more cars to race in EA's ode to speed demons in Need for Speed III? Company adds Lister Storm GTL.

Volition Continues Descent
Volition launches a revitalized web site and announces the development of three new titles.
Alan Dunkin
Deer Avenger Scores Top Billing
Simon & Schuster Interactive's Deer Avenger has taken the top-seeded position as the top-selling software title at Bubba-friendly Wal-Mart. The title is a spoof on the popular Deer Hunter series of titles where a deer gets behind the weapons to take out unsuspecting hunters.
Gamespot Staff
Cheating Caesar III
Being Caesar was never an easy task, just ask him. He was so bad at it, his own buddy stabbed him. Well, Sierra Studios and Impressions Software are hoping to make sure you don't get lynched by your followers in their latest title, Caesar III. The companies have released two cheat codes - a victory and a cash cheat - on its web site at www.caesar3.com.

GameSpot editor Tahsin Shamma got a look at Digital Anvil's upcoming RTS game, Conquest.

Harley Jebens
Power Stone Character Art
Want more Power Stone Capcom released character art of Power Stone
Games Trader Deal Delayed
Games Trader's closing of its acquisition of Triad Distributors Inc. and Global Star Software would be delayed slightly, the company said. The deal was to close on Nov. 26 but has been pushed back to Jan. 15, 1999. The delay is to "allow time for completion of due diligence investigation." GTI distributes used video games to retailers.

Even before the ink on the deal is dry, I-Magic is making use of MPG-Net's resources - in particular, MPG-Net's ICONS.

WinBack Delayed
Developers decide to take the time to do it right....
Moira Muldoon
Re-Volt Coming From Acclaim
Acclaim will be releasing remote-controlled car-racing sim Re-Volt, featuring 28 vehicles, 14 single-player tracks, and four multiplayer arenas, for the PlayStation, and Nintendo 64 formats, in summer '99. Racing environments will include a supermarket, museum, and rooftops in what might be likened to the Army Men of racing sims.

Mario Golf 64 Details
TOKYO - Camelot, the company behind Hot Shot Golf for the PlayStation, gives golf a go on the N64.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
All Your Eggs at Blockbuster
Blockbuster stores nationwide will be the only place where you'll be able to find Atlus' Eggs of Steel for the PlayStation. The title lets gamers control a night watchman named Charlie, who has to solve the mystery behind some machines that have gone on the fritz at the Momsteel Steel Factory.
Gamespot Staff
Shogo Play on MSN
Microsoft has opened its doors to support multiplayer matchmaking of Monolith's anime-inspired first-person shooter Shogo: Mobile Armor Division on the MSN Gaming Zone.

MSN Chooses Game Show Provider
Looking to play more game shows on the Web? MSN has inked a deal with Uproar to do just that.
Harley Jebens
Re-Volt Coming From Acclaim
Acclaim will be releasing remote-controlled car-racing sim Re-Volt, featuring 28 vehicles, 14 single-player tracks, and four multiplayer arenas for the PC during summer '99. Racing environments will include a supermarket, museum, and rooftops in what might be likened to the Army Men of racing sims.
Gamespot Staff
Sega's Secrets No Longer Safe
Sega will move North American operations to within whispering distance of GameSpot News. This could get interesting....
Gamespot Staff
South Park Aims for PC
Acclaim Entertainment is testing the gaming waters with its release of the console version of South Park for the N64. Developed in cooperation with Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the series' creators, it matches the feel and humor of the Comedy Central show. The PC version is slated to ship next month.
Gamespot Staff
Baldur's Gate Ships
Interplay's Baldur's Gate is out. The title is contained on five CD-ROMs for Windows 95/98. Baldur's Gate takes Advanced Dungeons & Dragons fans to the Sword Coast region of the Forgotten Realms campaign. Products begin shipping Monday so you just might have the game in time for Christmas.
Gamespot Staff
ION Adds to Daikatana Team
ION Storm has hired three new staffers and assigned them to John Romero's Daikatana team. ION has also reassigned three ION staffers to the team. The new hires are level designers Chris Klie and Bobby "Xcalibur" Pavlock and programmer Mike Montague.
Gamespot Staff
I Tawt I Taw Color
Need more titles for your Color Game Boy? Infogrames' Looney Tunes-inspired Twouble for the GBC has hit retail for those seeking to join in the antics of Sylvester and Tweety. Twouble is at most major retailers (for US$29.95). Infogrames will publish five additional Looney Tunes titles (N64, PS, and GBC) during 1999.
Gamespot Staff
Rewind: Week in Review
Sonic to appear online, NUON gets support, and Game Boy Color games enter the retail stream. Those and more stories made headlines this week.
Gamespot Staff
Uprising X Ships for PlayStation
The 3DO Company announced that Uprising X for the PlayStation has shipped. Gamers take control of a hi-tech assault tank called a Wraith Commander in over 20 levels in a fight to beat Imperium forces. Uprising X will retail for US$44.95.

Simutronics on MSN
Simutronics signed an agreement with Microsoft that will place Simutronics' Cyberstrike 2, GemStone III, Dragon Realms, and Hercules and Xena: Alliance of Heroes on the MSN Gaming Zone. Cyberstrike 2 is the first Simutronics title to go live on the Zone; you'll find the game in the Zone's Premium Games section. GemStone III will be next to go live.

The 3DO Company announced that action game Uprising 2: Lead and Destroy and turned-based strategy game Heroes of Might and Magic II Gold (a special limited-edition release containing the original game, The Succession Wars; the Price of Loyalty expansion pack; and 25 additional maps), are both available in retail stores.

Online Buyers Choose Games
Here's interesting news from PC Data, the folks that track PC game sales: When online shoppers go to the Web for holiday shopping this season, over 70 percent of those shoppers will buy computer products – and the most frequently purchased computer product is games.

Sonic Under the Tree
Several US mail-order outlets and retailers specializing in import titles have received copies of Sonic Adventure (released in Japan on Dec. 23). At least a few stores in the US are either guaranteeing that customers who prepurchased the title will receive it before Christmas or say they'll have it on shelves beginning today, the 23rd. Happy gaming!

Bust A Groove at the Arcade
Atlus announced that it will release Bust A Move (aka Bust a Groove in North America), Enix's dance and rhythm action game, in Japanese arcades next month. To release the game for the arcade, Atlus joined hands with Namco; the game will utilize Namco's PlayStation-compatible arcade board.

Ripcord Games has released an additional scenario for its 3D sci-fi multiplayer strategy game, Enemy Infestation. The additional scenario marks the beginning of a series of six scenarios set to release over the Internet from the game's official site at www.enemyinfestation.com.

Mo' PocketStation
Namco announced PocketStation compatibility with its cartoony baseball title World Stadium for the PlayStation. You can play various minigames with one of the stars of the game. World Stadium will be released in Japan in the spring of '99 and will also be NeGcon and Dual Shock compatible.

Love de Lic, creators of the PlayStation RPG Moon, are working on a new Dreamcast title called Lack of Love. Scheduled for release in Winter '98, your character has to establish a base for human life on a distant planet while dealing with the local dangers.

Mail-order house NCS is reporting that Sega's Naomi-based arcade title The House of the Dead 2 is now scheduled for a Dreamcast release - on March 18 in two forms: one just the game, the other with a light gun. This report has yet to be confirmed by an official announcement from Sega.

Gamespot Staff
Baldur's Gate Shortage?
GameSpot received a small number of tips on Monday that Baldur's Gate shipments have been nonexistent since a single round of deliveries before Christmas. A call to Electronics Boutique netted unofficial comments which confirmed the shortage. The high-profile game seems to be eluding gamers who are ready, willing, and able to purchase the title. More news on the game's availability on Tuesday.
Gamespot Staff
Rushdown From EA
Electronic Arts will publish an extreme sports title for the PlayStation. The title is called Rushdown, and EA calls it “an exhilarating, high-speed racing game.” Mountain biking, kayaking, and snowboarding are the game's sports. The game ships in early March.

Gamespot Staff
Aero Wings Review
Like Pilotwings 64, Aero Wings has realistic physics, and offers an authentic flying experience.
James Mielke
WWF Attitude Review
With a few more months, this game could have probably turned out a lot better.
Jeff Gerstmann
Armada Review
While Armada isn't for everyone, it is unique, fun, and original.
Peter Bartholow
Dance Dance Revolution 2nd Mix Dreamcast Edition (Import) Review
If you invest in one or two dancemats along with the game, Dance Dance Revolution is an amazingly fun game that you can play alone or in large groups, provided no one is too embarrassed to get busy in front of a crowd.
Jeff Gerstmann
House of the Dead 2 Review
Just a gun that lines up with the sights doesn't seem too much to ask for.
Joe Fielder
ECW Hardcore Revolution Review
ECW and its fans deserve better than this cookie-cutter approach to game design.
Jeff Gerstmann
South Park: Chef's Luv Shack Review
The repeating questions, repeating speech, and dull minigames keep it from being a game you'd want to pop in whenever you need a simple party-style game.
Jeff Gerstmann
July (Import) Review
July is a disturbingly bland choose-your-own-adventure book that just happened into a Dreamcast port.
Peter Bartholow
TNN Motorsports HardCore Heat Review
TNN Motorsports HardCore Heat lacks any real punch and comes off as one of the few throwaway titles available at launch.
Jeff Gerstmann
Blue Stinger Review
While it may disappoint dyed-in-the-wool Resident Evil fans, Dreamcast newcomers looking for an adventure fix on their new machine should be pleased.
Peter Bartholow
Time Stalkers Review
While Time Stalkers' story is passable enough, its contradictory dungeon, battle, and experience system undermines any hope you may have had of enjoying this game.
Peter Bartholow
ChuChu Rocket Review
In short, Sonic Team has created a party experience for the ages - like Bomberman, the best idea is to grab a bunch of friends and go head-to-head.
Christian Nutt
Centipede Review
While it's slightly better than its PlayStation brother, Centipede is still only average, at best.
Ben Stahl
Rainbow Cotton (Import) Review
While the game may sport a spiffy set of tech specs, Rainbow Cotton's core gameplay is so flawed that it leaves the overall experience unsalvageable.
Peter Bartholow
Expendable Review
Expendable is a refreshing blast of arcade gaming that never seems to get old.
James Mielke
Evolution Review
There is no real reason why RPG fans shouldn't go for this one; it's a genuinely satisfying experience, even if it is a bit textbook in execution and scope.
Christian Nutt
Sega Bass Fishing Review
More of a fishing game than a fishing simulator, Get Bass is a cool, if temporary, way to spend your time. No messy worms either.
James Mielke
NFL 2K Review
With NFL 2K's incredible control, you feel as though you're down on the field with the NFL's finest.
Hydro Thunder Review
The best boat-racing game to hit arcades has made its way to the Dreamcast - but what it hasn't done is brought anything new with it.
Ben Stahl
Kita He: White Illumination (Import) Review
Kita He ("to the north") is the first game in the uniquely Japanese genre of dating simulations to hit the Dreamcast.
Christian Nutt
Maken X Review
Maken X would make a great addition to an already strong library.
James Mielke
NBA Showtime: NBA on NBC Review
NBA Showtime is a fun game, but its longevity is directly linked to the number of friends you have who are interested in the game.
Jeff Gerstmann
NBA 2K Review
NBA 2K almost does for basketball what NFL 2K did for football.
Pen Pen TriIcelon Review
The game, as a whole, is a little too simplistic to hold the interest of most players, eventually relegating Pen Pen TriIcelon to the "especially good for younger players" category.
Jeff Gerstmann
NFL Quarterback Club 2000 Review
Quarterback Club 2000 is a buggy, problem-ridden football game that should be avoided by all football video game fans.
Puyo Puyo 4 (Import) Review
It's definitely a worthy and much-needed update to a long-running series.
Jeff Gerstmann
Puyo Puyo Da! (Import) Review
You can pick up Puyo Puyo Da! and be completely fed up with it within an hour.
Jeff Gerstmann
Psychic Force 2012 Review
What will make or break this game for you is really the original and unintuitive gameplay.
Christian Nutt
Suzuki Alstare Extreme Racing Review
This one says "rental" all over it.
James Mielke
Rayman 2: The Great Escape Review
Rayman 2 is one of the best platforming experiences available today.
Ben Stahl
Virtua Cop 2 (Import) Review
What we have on display is a criminal waste of resources.
James Mielke
Vigilante 8: Second Offense Review
Combining the fantastic audio from the PlayStation edition, the four-player mode offered on the Nintendo 64, and the graphical advances you expect from the Dreamcast, this version of V8SO is clearly the best of the three.
Joe Fielder
Antz Review
Antz on the GBC is another platform game that will amuse those who find the genre enjoyable in small scale 8-bit.
Lauren Fielder
Aero Star Review
Aero Star adds a slightly new skew to the top-down blaster concept.
Cameron Davis
Frogger Review
Frogger is one of those gaming archetypes that has remained basically unaltered since it made its coin-op debut.
Cameron Davis
FIFA '98 - Road to the World Cup Review
This is a great conversion of the 16- and 32-bit franchise of the same name.
Cameron Davis
Evel Knievel Review
Evel Knievel is all about precision - knowing when to tap what, how hard, and for how long is integral to making an enjoyable experience out of this game.
Miguel Lopez
ECW Hardcore Revolution Review
Take last year's WWF Attitude, strip out the WWF license, insert the ECW characters, and voila - a new game to release in 2000.
Frank Provo
Dogz Review
There's really nothing to do other than to turn your Game Boy on, watch your dog run around the screen, and wonder why you're wasting your time with this title.
Doug Trueman
Catz Review
Don't be fooled into thinking that Catz (or its sister title, Dogz) is actually a game.
Doug Trueman
Bionic Commando Review
You may occasionally find yourself longing for the levels and graphical style of the original game, but the new model doesn't disappoint in any way.
Jeff Gerstmann
Babe and Friends Review
While this title isn't going to win any awards, it's a satisfying way to spend some free time.
Doug Trueman
Army Men Review
Taken as a whole, Army Men is an enjoyable game that delivers the pleasingly nostalgic experience of plastic-soldier warfare.
Frank Provo
Smurf's Nightmare Review
There are inevitably going to be a dozen or so average platformers in your Game Boy collection, one of them might as well be this.
Cameron Davis
Street Fighter Alpha Review
Street Fighter Alpha stands alone as the best fighting game to ever hit the Game Boy.
Jeff Gerstmann
Rugrats: The Movie Review
Rugrats: The Movie for the Game Boy is the only way you can relive the surprise hit without buying a VCR
Cameron Davis
R-Type DX Review
R-Type DX is one of the best shooters you can get for any machine, and the GBC version does the series proud.
Cameron Davis

At the outset, Polaris SnoCross is an above-average racer that delivers the "extreme" experience, while including an oft-neglected link-play feature.
Frank Provo
NHL 2000 Review
Even hard-core hockey fans should avoid this title; it will start gathering dust on its first day of play.
Doug Trueman
NASCAR Challenge Review
NASCAR Challenge is a dull racing game that doesn't have much going for it.
Doug Trueman
Mortal Kombat 4 Review
People looking for portable fighting-game action would do well to wait for Street Fighter Alpha, a much more responsive fighting game.
Jeff Gerstmann
Mission: Impossible Review
Mission: Impossible seems geared to those hard-core gamers out there who have both the time and the patience to spend replaying level after level until they've finished the game.
Frank Provo
Men in Black: The Series Review
The Men In Black franchise had such an opportunity to be a good video game - wild alien characters, cool weapons, stylish black suits - but what we have here is a complete waste of potential.
Cameron Davis

Overall, it's a great version of a real classic.
Jeff Gerstmann

In the Zone '99 can deliver fun gameplay, especially with multiplayer games and three-point shooting contests, if gamers accept its defensive AI and speed flaws.

NFL Blitz is the best football game ever made.

Lauren Fielder
Star Wars: Shadows of the Empire Review
Problems with the control, camera angles, and frustrating save feature keep Shadows from reaching its full potential.
John Broady
Shadow Man Review

Nelson Taruc

Glenn Rubenstein

Its gameplay is diverse yet solid, and it all combines to form a game that will keep you interested for quite some time.

South Park Rally is a poor racing game that tries to capture the look and feel of the show with a few cute quips and phrases that become annoying after just a couple of races.
Space Invaders Review
Space Invaders is a game different enough to cancel any feelings of nostalgia, yet it isn't good enough to stand on its own.
Jeff Gerstmann

Nelson Taruc

Auto Destruct Review
Auto Destruct could've been a modernized city-based version of Midway's Spy Hunter, but it ended up as a G Police that got grounded.
Joe Fielder
Ballistic Review
Despite the simplistic nature of the game and sheer mediocrity of many of the game elements, Ballistic is still a fairly fun puzzle game with a refreshingly new premise.
Ben Stahl
Ballblazer Champions Review
Ballblazer Champions has everything that a remake could want.
Trent Ward
Backstreet Billiards Review
It's the most complete pool-simulation game around for the PlayStation.
Nelson Taruc
MLB 2001 Review
Pacing and sound issues aside, 989 Studios has fixed many of the glaring flaws of last year's release and as such has created a game superior to EA's offering.
Frank Provo
Eurogamer
